title: Acts Chapter 26 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Acts chapter 26 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Acts Chapter 26 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Acts Chapter 26.

questions.question: Who permitted Paul to speak for himself in Acts 26?
options: King Agrippa
Festus
Bernice
The chief priests
questions.correctAnswer: King Agrippa
questions.explanation: Acts 26:1 states that Agrippa said unto Paul, 'Thou art permitted to speak for thyself.'

questions.question: What was Paul especially happy about in answering before King Agrippa?
options: Because Agrippa was expert in Jewish customs and questions
Because Festus was present
Because he was free
Because he was in Rome
questions.correctAnswer: Because Agrippa was expert in Jewish customs and questions
questions.explanation: Acts 26:3 explains Paul knew Agrippa was expert in all customs and questions among the Jews.

questions.question: From what sect of religion did Paul say he lived as a Pharisee?
options: The strictest sect
The Sadducees
The Essenes
The Samaritans
questions.correctAnswer: The strictest sect
questions.explanation: Acts 26:5 states Paul lived after the most straitest sect of their religion as a Pharisee.

questions.question: For what hope did Paul say he was judged and accused by the Jews?
options: The hope of the promise made of God unto their fathers
The hope of becoming king
The hope of wealth
The hope of peace with Rome
questions.correctAnswer: The hope of the promise made of God unto their fathers
questions.explanation: Acts 26:6-7 shows Paul stands judged for the hope of the promise made by God to their fathers.

questions.question: What did Paul say he thought he ought to do contrary to the name of Jesus of Nazareth?
options: Do many things
Preach openly
Build synagogues
Write letters
questions.correctAnswer: Do many things
questions.explanation: Acts 26:9 says Paul thought he ought to do many things contrary to the name of Jesus of Nazareth.

questions.question: Where was Paul going when he saw the light from heaven?
options: Damascus
Jerusalem
Judaea
Rome
questions.correctAnswer: Damascus
questions.explanation: Acts 26:12-13 explains Paul was going to Damascus when he saw the light from heaven.

questions.question: What did the voice from heaven say to Paul in Hebrew?
options: Saul, Saul, why persecutest thou me?
Paul, Paul, stand up
Saul, Saul, follow me
Paul, Paul, be strong
questions.correctAnswer: Saul, Saul, why persecutest thou me?
questions.explanation: Acts 26:14 records the voice saying, 'Saul, Saul, why persecutest thou me?' in Hebrew.

questions.question: Who did the voice identify itself as in Acts 26?
options: Jesus
An angel
Moses
God the Father
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus
questions.explanation: Acts 26:15 shows the voice said, 'I am Jesus whom thou persecutest.'

questions.question: What was Paul's appointed mission according to the vision?
options: To make him a minister and witness
To build a church
To write scriptures
To lead an army
questions.correctAnswer: To make him a minister and witness
questions.explanation: Acts 26:16 states Paul was made a minister and witness of things he had seen and would see.

questions.question: What is Paul sent to do among the Gentiles, according to Acts 26?
options: Open their eyes and turn them from darkness to light
Make them pay taxes
Build synagogues
Teach the Roman law
questions.correctAnswer: Open their eyes and turn them from darkness to light
questions.explanation: Acts 26:17-18 explains Paul was sent to open Gentiles' eyes and turn them from darkness to light.

questions.question: True or False: Paul says he was disobedient to the heavenly vision he received.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Acts 26:19 states Paul was not disobedient unto the heavenly vision.

questions.question: True or False: Paul witnessed to both small and great about the things foretold by prophets and Moses.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Acts 26:22 says Paul witnessed to small and great, saying none other things than those prophesied by Moses and the prophets.

questions.question: True or False: Festus accused Paul of being mad because of much learning.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Acts 26:24 records Festus saying Paul was beside himself, much learning makes him mad.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Acts 26:28: 'Almost thou persuadest me to be a ______.'
options: Christian
Pharisee
Roman
Samaritan
questions.correctAnswer: Christian
questions.explanation: Acts 26:28 records Agrippa saying, 'Almost thou persuadest me to be a Christian.'

questions.question: What did the people say about Paul after he finished speaking?
options: This man doeth nothing worthy of death or of bonds
This man is a great threat
This man should be punished
This man is a liar
questions.correctAnswer: This man doeth nothing worthy of death or of bonds
questions.explanation: Acts 26:31 says after Paul spoke, they said he did nothing worthy of death or bonds.

medium.title: Acts Chapter 26 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Acts Chapter 26 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with persecution for their faith. Based on Paul's experience in Acts 26, what biblical truth would you share about perseverance?
options: God provides help to continue witnessing faithfully
Persecution means God has abandoned you
One should avoid any conflict to stay safe
Faith is only for those without suffering
questions.correctAnswer: God provides help to continue witnessing faithfully
questions.explanation: Paul states in Acts 26:22 that he has obtained help from God and continues witnessing despite opposition. Verses 20 and 21 show that he preached repentance even in the face of threats, teaching perseverance through God's help.

questions.question: How does Paul's testimony in Acts 26 teach us about obedience to God's calling when facing challenges?
options: He was not disobedient to the heavenly vision
He ignored the vision and followed his own plans
He only obeyed when it was convenient
He avoided difficult assignments
questions.correctAnswer: He was not disobedient to the heavenly vision
questions.explanation: Paul explicitly says in Acts 26:19 that he was not disobedient to the heavenly vision. This shows the importance of faithful obedience even when the path is difficult, as seen also in verses 16-18 where God commissions him.

questions.question: A believer doubts the resurrection of the dead. Based on Acts 26, how would you encourage their faith?
options: God is able to raise the dead, and this is foundational to our hope
Resurrection is just a metaphor
The dead never truly live again
Faith does not require belief in resurrection
questions.correctAnswer: God is able to raise the dead, and this is foundational to our hope
questions.explanation: Paul challenges Agrippa in Acts 26:8 about why it should be incredible that God raises the dead. He connects resurrection to the hope promised to the twelve tribes in verses 6-7, framing it as central to faith.

questions.question: Based on Paul's example in Acts 26, what attitude should we have when sharing the Gospel with both Jews and Gentiles?
options: We should share the message everywhere, calling people to repentance
We should only share with those who agree with us
We should avoid Gentiles altogether
We should force people to accept the faith
questions.correctAnswer: We should share the message everywhere, calling people to repentance
questions.explanation: Paul describes in Acts 26:20 how he preached repentance to Jews and Gentiles throughout Judaea and beyond, showing a broad and patient evangelistic approach grounded in calling others to turn to God.

questions.question: How does Acts 26 illustrate the importance of humility and contentment even while suffering for faith?
options: Paul accepted his bonds but longed for others to share his faith
Paul was proud and boastful about his suffering
Paul wished he was free from all trials
Paul rejected his calling due to hardships
questions.correctAnswer: Paul accepted his bonds but longed for others to share his faith
questions.explanation: In Acts 26:29, Paul expresses a humble desire that others might be as he is, except for the chains. This shows contentment in suffering combined with love and longing for others' salvation.

questions.question: A believer is tempted to become bitter after facing rejection. What lesson from Acts 26 encourages forgiveness and love for neighbors?
options: Paul continued witnessing with truth and soberness despite opposition
Paul called for vengeance on his enemies
Paul stopped preaching after being rejected
Paul spoke harshly against those who opposed him
questions.correctAnswer: Paul continued witnessing with truth and soberness despite opposition
questions.explanation: Acts 26:25 shows Paul responding calmly and truthfully instead of bitterness when accused of madness. His example teaches responding with grace and love even under rejection.

questions.question: What does Paul's experience teach about the role of spiritual discipline and openness to God's voice?
options: Paul listened and obeyed the voice from heaven that called him
Paul ignored the vision and continued his own plans
Spiritual experiences are irrelevant to faith
One should avoid listening to heavenly messages
questions.correctAnswer: Paul listened and obeyed the voice from heaven that called him
questions.explanation: Acts 26:14-16 records Paul's encounter with Jesus' voice and his obedient response to stand and serve as a witness, emphasizing the importance of spiritual attentiveness and discipline.

questions.question: True or False: According to Acts 26, Paul was judged worthy of death because of his actions.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Acts 26:31 states that those discussing Paul agreed he did nothing worthy of death or bonds, indicating his innocence in their judgment.

questions.question: True or False: Paul's hope in the promise of God is linked to the expectations of the twelve tribes of Israel.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: In Acts 26:6-7, Paul connects his hope to the promise made to the twelve tribes who serve God day and night, showing continuity with Israel's faith heritage.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Paul was accused by the Jews because of the _______ they hoped to receive according to the promise of God.
options: hope
wealth
power
fame
questions.correctAnswer: hope
questions.explanation: Acts 26:7 explains Paul stood judged for the hope of the promise made by God to their fathers, which the twelve tribes hoped to receive.

questions.question: According to Acts 26, how does Paul's example encourage honesty and integrity in daily life?
options: Paul openly states his past as a Pharisee and persecution of Christians
Paul hides his past to appear better
Paul exaggerates his story for sympathy
Paul avoids discussing his background
questions.correctAnswer: Paul openly states his past as a Pharisee and persecution of Christians
questions.explanation: Acts 26:4-11 reveals Paul honestly recounting his background and actions, demonstrating integrity by not hiding or denying difficult truths about himself.

questions.question: What does Paul's interaction with King Agrippa teach about sharing the Gospel with respect and understanding?
options: Paul respectfully appeals to Agrippa's knowledge of Jewish customs
Paul insults Agrippa to prove his point
Paul ignores Agrippa's perspective
Paul preaches without considering his audience
questions.correctAnswer: Paul respectfully appeals to Agrippa's knowledge of Jewish customs
questions.explanation: Acts 26:3 shows Paul appealing to Agrippa's expertise in Jewish customs, indicating a respectful and thoughtful approach to evangelism tailored to the listener's background.

questions.question: How does Acts 26 show the importance of prayerful reflection and spiritual awareness in ministry?
options: Paul's encounter on the road to Damascus was a pivotal moment of spiritual revelation
Paul acted impulsively without seeking God
Paul relied only on his own strength
Spiritual experiences are unimportant for ministry
questions.correctAnswer: Paul's encounter on the road to Damascus was a pivotal moment of spiritual revelation
questions.explanation: Acts 26:12-18 describes Paul's dramatic encounter with Jesus that transformed his ministry, illustrating the critical role of spiritual awareness and dependence on God.

questions.question: What lesson on stewardship and responsibility can be drawn from Paul's commission in Acts 26?
options: Paul was sent to open eyes and turn people to God, carrying a serious responsibility
Paul avoided responsibility by hiding
Paul was careless with his mission
Stewardship is not important in spiritual matters
questions.correctAnswer: Paul was sent to open eyes and turn people to God, carrying a serious responsibility
questions.explanation: Acts 26:17-18 shows Paul’s commission to bring people from darkness to light, emphasizing the responsibility entrusted to believers for evangelism and spiritual guidance.

questions.question: How does Paul's response to Festus in Acts 26 teach us to speak with truth and soberness in difficult situations?
options: Paul calmly asserts he is not mad but speaks truthfully
Paul reacts angrily and defensively
Paul tries to avoid the question
Paul uses flattery to appease Festus
questions.correctAnswer: Paul calmly asserts he is not mad but speaks truthfully
questions.explanation: Acts 26:24-25 shows Paul responding to Festus’ accusation by firmly and calmly affirming his sobriety and truthfulness, modeling how to maintain integrity under pressure.

hard.title: Acts Chapter 26 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Acts Chapter 26.

questions.question: In Acts 26, Paul appeals to King Agrippa's knowledge of Jewish customs and beliefs. What is the significance of Paul addressing Agrippa in this way?
options: To establish common ground and show respect for Agrippa’s expertise
To intimidate Agrippa with his knowledge of Jewish law
To convert Agrippa immediately through argument
To distract Agrippa from the accusations against him
questions.correctAnswer: To establish common ground and show respect for Agrippa’s expertise
questions.explanation: In Acts 26:3, Paul acknowledges Agrippa’s expertise in Jewish customs and questions, which serves to establish a respectful dialogue and common ground for his defense.

questions.question: Paul identifies himself with which strict sect of Judaism in his early life?
options: Pharisees
Sadducees
Essenes
Zealots
questions.correctAnswer: Pharisees
questions.explanation: Acts 26:5 explicitly states that Paul lived after the strictest sect of their religion, identifying himself as a Pharisee.

questions.question: Paul argues in Acts 26:8 that the resurrection of the dead should not be considered incredible. Which Old Testament belief is this most directly connected to?
options: The resurrection hope found in Daniel 12
The covenant with Abraham in Genesis 15
The Exodus deliverance in Exodus 12
The building of the Temple in 1 Kings
questions.correctAnswer: The resurrection hope found in Daniel 12
questions.explanation: The resurrection theme Paul references is closely linked to the apocalyptic hope expressed in Daniel 12, which was well known among Jews and connects to the belief in life after death.

questions.question: What was the nature of Paul's mission as revealed by Jesus in the vision on the road to Damascus?
options: To be a minister and witness of what he had seen and would see
To lead a political revolt against Rome
To establish a new Jewish sect
To become a priest in the Temple
questions.correctAnswer: To be a minister and witness of what he had seen and would see
questions.explanation: In Acts 26:16, Jesus tells Paul he is appointed to be a minister and witness of the things he has seen and those that will appear to him, indicating a prophetic and apostolic role.

questions.question: The phrase 'kick against the pricks' in Acts 26:14 is an example of what kind of literary device?
options: Greek idiom indicating resistance to authority
Hebrew metaphor illustrating futility of opposition
Roman legal phrase referring to rebellion
Egyptian proverb about patience
questions.correctAnswer: Hebrew metaphor illustrating futility of opposition
questions.explanation: The phrase is a Hebrew metaphor meaning to resist or oppose something in a way that only causes harm to oneself, showing the futility of resisting divine will (Acts 26:14).

questions.question: Which Greek term translated as 'minister' in Acts 26:16 conveys the meaning of a servant or one who carries out a divine commission?
options: Diakonos
Apostolos
Presbyteros
Episkopos
questions.correctAnswer: Diakonos
questions.explanation: The Greek word 'diakonos' means servant or minister and is used in Acts 26:16 to describe Paul's role of serving God’s purpose.

questions.question: How does Paul's description of his mission 'to open their eyes and turn them from darkness to light' connect with Old Testament prophetic themes?
options: It echoes Isaiah’s prophecy about spiritual enlightenment
It refers to the Exodus pillar of fire
It relates to the building of the Temple
It parallels Moses’ miracles in Egypt
questions.correctAnswer: It echoes Isaiah’s prophecy about spiritual enlightenment
questions.explanation: Acts 26:18 reflects Isaiah 42:7, where God promises to open blind eyes and bring people from darkness to light, highlighting fulfillment of prophecy through Paul’s mission.

questions.question: Paul claims in Acts 26 to have preached repentance and works worthy of repentance to which groups?
options: Jews and Gentiles
Only Jews
Only Gentiles
Roman officials
questions.correctAnswer: Jews and Gentiles
questions.explanation: Acts 26:20 states Paul preached repentance to both Jews and Gentiles, emphasizing the universal scope of his ministry.

questions.question: What is Festus’s reaction to Paul’s defense, and what cultural context might explain this reaction?
options: He thinks Paul is mad due to excessive learning, reflecting Roman skepticism toward Greek philosophy
He praises Paul’s wisdom as a learned man
He ignores Paul’s speech due to political pressure
He immediately orders Paul’s release
questions.correctAnswer: He thinks Paul is mad due to excessive learning, reflecting Roman skepticism toward Greek philosophy
questions.explanation: Festus’s claim in Acts 26:24 that Paul’s learning made him mad reflects a Roman cultural stereotype that intellectualism could be linked to madness.

questions.question: In Acts 26, how does Paul demonstrate his awareness of Agrippa’s beliefs and knowledge?
options: By asserting that Agrippa believes the prophets
By challenging Agrippa’s faith openly
By ignoring Agrippa’s opinions
By appealing only to Roman law
questions.correctAnswer: By asserting that Agrippa believes the prophets
questions.explanation: Paul directly says to Agrippa in Acts 26:27, 'I know that thou believest,' showing his confidence in Agrippa’s familiarity with Jewish prophecy.

questions.question: Which theme in Acts 26:23 directly foreshadows the New Testament emphasis on Jesus’ resurrection as central to Christian faith?
options: Christ suffering and being the first to rise from the dead
The establishment of the Temple worship
Observance of the Mosaic Law
The coming of the Messiah as a political leader
questions.correctAnswer: Christ suffering and being the first to rise from the dead
questions.explanation: Acts 26:23 summarizes the gospel message focusing on Christ’s suffering and resurrection, a cornerstone of Christian doctrine developed in the New Testament.

questions.question: True or False: Paul claims he was disobedient to the heavenly vision he received on the road to Damascus.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Acts 26:19 explicitly states Paul was not disobedient to the heavenly vision, indicating his submission to God’s calling.

questions.question: The appeal Paul made to Caesar, referenced in Acts 26:32, illustrates what aspect of Roman legal practice?
options: The right of a Roman citizen to appeal to the emperor
The necessity of local judges to decide all cases
The prohibition of appeals in religious matters
The automatic death sentence for appeals
questions.correctAnswer: The right of a Roman citizen to appeal to the emperor
questions.explanation: Acts 26:32 shows Paul exercising his legal right as a Roman citizen to appeal to Caesar for trial, reflecting Roman judicial procedures.

questions.question: What literary technique is suggested by the structure of Paul's speech in Acts 26, starting with his past life, his conversion, and then his mission?
options: Chiasm, highlighting transformation and divine purpose
Parable, using metaphorical storytelling
Genealogy, tracing lineage
Apocalyptic prophecy, revealing end times
questions.correctAnswer: Chiasm, highlighting transformation and divine purpose
questions.explanation: The speech has a chiastic structure moving from past to present and future mission, emphasizing Paul's transformation and God’s providence (Acts 26 overall).

questions.question: Paul’s mention of the 'hope of the promise made of God unto our fathers' (Acts 26:6) refers to what major biblical theme?
options: The Messianic promise and resurrection hope
The covenant of circumcision
The building of the Temple
The conquest of Canaan
questions.correctAnswer: The Messianic promise and resurrection hope
questions.explanation: Paul refers to the Jewish expectation of the Messiah and the resurrection, a central hope tied to God’s promises to the patriarchs (Acts 26:6-7).

theological.title: Acts Chapter 26 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Acts Chapter 26 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Paul in Acts 26, what was the basis of his hope for which he was being judged?
options: The promise made by God to the fathers
His Pharisaic zeal for the law
His Roman citizenship privileges
His knowledge of Jewish customs
questions.correctAnswer: The promise made by God to the fathers
questions.explanation: Paul states that he is judged for the hope of the promise made by God to their fathers (Acts 26:6), which aligns with Old Testament promises given to the patriarchs (Genesis 12:1-3; Psalm 105:8-11; Isaiah 9:6-7; Jeremiah 31:31-34).

questions.question: What did Paul claim was incredible to some but true concerning God, as he addressed King Agrippa?
options: That God should raise the dead
That the Gentiles are included in salvation
That the Messiah would suffer
That the law would be fulfilled by grace
questions.correctAnswer: That God should raise the dead
questions.explanation: Paul asks why it should be thought incredible that God raises the dead (Acts 26:8), a foundational doctrine consistent with Old Testament teaching (Job 19:25-27; Psalm 16:9-11; Isaiah 26:19; Daniel 12:2).

questions.question: Before his conversion, how did Paul describe his actions toward the followers of Jesus?
options: Persecuting them violently and imprisoning many
Preaching the law in synagogues
Seeking to understand their teachings
Helping spread the gospel
questions.correctAnswer: Persecuting them violently and imprisoning many
questions.explanation: Paul recounts that he imprisoned many saints and gave his voice against them (Acts 26:10), consistent with his earlier zeal as a Pharisee opposing the followers of Christ (Philippians 3:6; Galatians 1:13; 1 Timothy 1:13).

questions.question: What extraordinary event occurred to Paul on the way to Damascus?
options: A light from heaven brighter than the sun shone around him
He was struck down by a Roman soldier
He had a vision of angels
He received the law anew
questions.correctAnswer: A light from heaven brighter than the sun shone around him
questions.explanation: Paul saw a heavenly light above the brightness of the sun shining around him and those traveling with him (Acts 26:13), symbolizing divine revelation similar to theophanies in the Old Testament (Exodus 34:29-35; Isaiah 6:1-5; Ezekiel 1:4-28).

questions.question: What did the voice from heaven say to Paul during his encounter on the road?
options: "Saul, Saul, why persecutest thou me?"
"Fear not, for I am with thee"
"Go and preach to the Gentiles"
"I am the God of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob"
questions.correctAnswer: "Saul, Saul, why persecutest thou me?"
questions.explanation: The voice said, 'Saul, Saul, why persecutest thou me?' (Acts 26:14), indicating the unity of Christ with His followers, echoing Old Testament themes of God identifying with His people (Exodus 3:7-8; Isaiah 63:9; Hosea 2:23; Zechariah 2:8).

questions.question: Who did the voice reveal itself to be when Paul asked who was speaking?
options: Jesus
An angel of the Lord
God the Father
Moses
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus
questions.explanation: The voice identified itself as Jesus whom Paul was persecuting (Acts 26:15), affirming Christ's divine identity and role as the risen Lord (John 14:6; Colossians 1:18; Hebrews 1:3; Revelation 1:17-18).

questions.question: What purpose did Jesus state for appearing to Paul?
options: To make Paul a minister and witness of what he had seen and would see
To appoint Paul as a Pharisee leader
To command Paul to follow the law strictly
To bring Paul back to Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: To make Paul a minister and witness of what he had seen and would see
questions.explanation: Jesus said He appeared to Paul to make him a minister and witness of things seen and those to come (Acts 26:16), fulfilling the prophetic call to be a witness for Christ (Isaiah 49:6; Jeremiah 1:5; Luke 24:46-48; Revelation 1:5-6).

questions.question: What mission did Jesus assign to Paul regarding the Gentiles?
options: To open their eyes and turn them from darkness to light
To keep them separated from Israel
To teach them the Jewish law
To exclude them from the promise
questions.correctAnswer: To open their eyes and turn them from darkness to light
questions.explanation: Paul was sent to open the Gentiles’ eyes, turning them from darkness to light and from Satan's power to God to receive forgiveness (Acts 26:17-18), reflecting Old Testament prophecy about Gentile inclusion (Isaiah 42:6; Isaiah 49:6; Jeremiah 16:19; Ezekiel 36:26-27).

questions.question: How did Paul respond to the heavenly vision he received?
options: He was not disobedient
He fled from it in fear
He ignored it for a time
He doubted its truth
questions.correctAnswer: He was not disobedient
questions.explanation: Paul declares he was not disobedient to the heavenly vision (Acts 26:19), showing faithful obedience to God's call consistent with biblical examples of prophets and servants responding to divine revelation (Jonah 1:1-3; Isaiah 6:8; Jeremiah 1:7-8; Hebrews 11:5-6).

questions.question: What did Paul preach to both Jews and Gentiles after his conversion?
options: Repentance towards God and works meet for repentance
Strict adherence to the Mosaic Law
Only faith without works
Judgment without mercy
questions.correctAnswer: Repentance towards God and works meet for repentance
questions.explanation: Paul preached repentance and works appropriate to repentance (Acts 26:20), harmonizing faith and obedience (Joel 2:12-13; Isaiah 55:6-7; Matthew 3:8; James 2:17).

questions.question: According to Paul, what was foretold by the prophets and Moses about the Messiah?
options: That Christ should suffer and be the first to rise from the dead
That Christ would reign without suffering
That Christ would come only for Israel
That Christ would abolish the law
questions.correctAnswer: That Christ should suffer and be the first to rise from the dead
questions.explanation: Paul affirms that the prophets predicted the Messiah’s suffering and resurrection as the first to rise (Acts 26:23), consistent with Isaiah 53, Psalm 16:10, and Daniel 9:26, which highlight the redemptive suffering and victorious resurrection of Christ.

questions.question: How did Festus react to Paul's defense before King Agrippa?
options: He said Paul was mad due to much learning
He immediately released Paul
He praised Paul's wisdom
He accused Paul of blasphemy
questions.correctAnswer: He said Paul was mad due to much learning
questions.explanation: Festus exclaimed Paul was beside himself and that much learning made him mad (Acts 26:24), reflecting skepticism toward gospel truths, a challenge addressed in Scripture (1 Corinthians 1:18-25; John 7:48; Acts 17:18).

questions.question: What was Paul's response to Festus's accusation of madness?
options: He said he was speaking words of truth and soberness
He remained silent
He called Festus ignorant
He confessed to being troubled
questions.correctAnswer: He said he was speaking words of truth and soberness
questions.explanation: Paul denied madness and affirmed he spoke truth and soberness (Acts 26:25), consistent with his many sober and reasoned defenses in Scripture (2 Timothy 2:15; 1 Peter 3:15; Acts 24:25).

questions.question: What did Paul affirm about King Agrippa’s knowledge of the matters he was discussing?
options: That the king knew about these things and none were hidden from him
That the king was ignorant of the Jewish law
That the king did not believe the prophets
That the king was new to these customs
questions.correctAnswer: That the king knew about these things and none were hidden from him
questions.explanation: Paul said King Agrippa knew of these things and none were hidden from him (Acts 26:26), indicating the public and well-known nature of gospel claims, consistent with Old Testament and New Testament prophetic fulfillment (Psalm 119:105; Isaiah 40:21-22; Luke 24:25-27).

questions.question: How did King Agrippa respond to Paul's message about Christ?
options: He said, 'Almost thou persuadest me to be a Christian.'
He immediately accepted Christ
He rejected Paul and ordered his imprisonment
He asked Paul to stop speaking
questions.correctAnswer: He said, 'Almost thou persuadest me to be a Christian.'
questions.explanation: Agrippa expressed near persuasion to believe (Acts 26:28), showing how Paul's witness confronted listeners with the gospel, similar to responses in Acts 13:43 and Acts 17:32.
